Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Data Analytics on Honeybee Hives Using IoT Sensor Data
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is a healthier honeybee population to increase food security. According to the Food and Agriculture Organization, annual production must increase by 60% from 2007 to produce enough food for an estimated 9.1 billion people by 2050, which will be impossible without honeybee pollination (Food and Agriculture Organization, 2012). Honeybee populations have declined precipitously for the past 60 years?a total loss of 3 million hives (National Agricultural Statistics Service, 2007). Annual hive losses cost the U.S. economy $2 billion (National Agricultural Statistics Service, 2016; The White House, 2014). This project aims to enhance scientific understanding of the problem by finding practical solutions to hive loss for beekeepers, advancing IoT applications in beekeeping, and automating data analysis for beekeepers. Researchers and experts suspect the declines are due to multiple factors, but research is limited by a lack of technology tracking the hives on a large scale. Researchers' inability to perform analysis on a large, diverse dataset has obstructed their ability to draw conclusions on causes of hive loss and drive innovation on traditional beekeeping methods.Â 

This proposed project will advance Internet of Things applications in beekeeping by automating data analysis for beekeepers through algorithm building. Several studies built models to describe actions inside the hive. However, these are built on limited data or are theoretical. Henry et al., 2016 mentioned the need for predictive algorithms to be expanded to larger data sets to reduce hive loss. Data driven beekeeping is in its infancy as an industry, but based on the success in the AgTech space, data monitoring will be a necessary step in solving colony health problems. The project will take a database of over 4,000 hives to improve research models for practical monitoring. This database will be paired with sensor and monitoring data from project hives. Through the project hives the company will confirm the sensor quality for commercialization. The company will create a baseline model of a healthy hive to detect anomalies. These anomalies will be worked into a predictive model to detect problems related to pests and diseases in the hive. The company will look for broad detection of a threatened hive, then drill down into specific problems (like Varroa mites). These finds will be included in monitoring products offered to beekeepers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For growers who understand hive strength is important but lack a way to measure pollination efficacy, Verifli is an infrared image analysis tool for pollination that allows growers to determine pollination value and use results to protect yield. The Bee Corp's Phase I research proved the viability of Verifli both from a commercial and a technical feasibility perspective. An MVP was built and tested through paid pilots which also proved willingness to pay for the product.

Growers of over 90 crops in the U.S. rent honeybees to pollinate their crops. Through interviews with growers, The Bee Corp determined that the increasing cost of pollination and the issue of ensuring quality of beehives are major pains. If growers don't rent enough hives above a minimum strength, they will produce lower yields that season. Growers price hives based on colony strength, measured by the population of bees inside the hive. Growers hire inspectors to count the number of frames of bees inside the hive to estimate colony strength across a small sample of hives. Growers told The Bee Corp through customer discovery interviews that these inspections are slow, inaccurate, and stressful to the bees.

Verifli replaces the manual inspection process by using infrared imagery and proprietary algorithms to calculate colony strength. Compared to manual inspections, Verifli is faster, more accurate, and noninvasive. Growers collect images with an infrared camera smartphone attachment and an application uploads the images to The Bee Corp database. The application processes the image and reports colony strength to the user, in number of frames covered by bees. 

Modeling hive population from infrared images was a major component of the Phase I grant. This included image processing and segmenting, exploratory data analysis, statistical modeling, feature engineering, model optimization, and performance testing. To build these models, ambient, biological, and thermodynamic factors were included to account for heat effects on the infrared image not caused by the bees. The parameters of the models were optimized to reduce error, and the model was tested on unseen data to determine how accurately it predicts hive population. The Bee Corp built software to automate the processing of IR images, run the hive strength model, and generate results in a web-based report.

Every time The Bee Corp collected new data from hives, they would first run predictions on the infrared images to compare how the model was performing. This allowed The Bee Corp to treat each data collection day as a mini pilot and continually test the performance of the model on unseen data. The Bee Corp also conducted several pilots at scale during Phase I, including two initial unpaid pilots with an Indiana commercial beekeeper and a California pollination broker. The Bee Corp offered Verifli to a select group of almond growers through a paid pilot in February 2019. These pilots demonstrate a willingness to pay by the customers and allowed The Bee Corp to test the product at scale.
